summary: Gaeton Fonzi was a staff member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The documents indicate that in May 1978, Fonzi, along with Albert Gonzales, visited Guayaquil and Caracas as part of the HSCA's investigation. A CIA cable discusses their upcoming visit and requests guidance on whether to expect contact from them. Another cable mentions a meeting in Rio de Janeiro involving Cuban CI officers and alleged CIA officers, focusing on reviewing the JFK and Letelier assassinations, though Fonzi's direct involvement in this meeting is not specified in the provided documents.
significance: Gaeton Fonzi's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his role as a staff member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), which was tasked with reinvestigating the assassination. His visits to places like Guayaquil as part of the HSCA suggest he was actively involved in gathering information and investigating potential leads related to the assassination.
